content.description: This is a really fun problem. SDS on the far right side in a couple of bomber huecos. Bust up and left across a good rail and huge huecos with right foot heel hooks. Then do a difficult throw, and match over the blank section (crux) to easier climbing to the left of the boulder.
content.protection: A couple pads as the line traverses.
content.location: Park where the 4WD road branches left, and hike up the open meadow with boulders on the right and left. This problem is on the left side and can be seen easily from the meadow.

content.description: With 2 bolts for protection, this is a beautiful, striking, overhung arÃªte.
SDS on an awesome rail and climb compression features to top.

This is a fantastic lip traverse! Sit start on the furthest left holds on the lip. Traverse the lip to the right, eventually continue by dropping into the seam, round the corner, and top out on the hueco prow.
content.protection: Pads. Watch out for mountain bikers.
content.location: It is on the East face of the Seam Boulder. The Monster Slayer mountain bike trail runs directly under this problem. I recommend blocking the trail with a backpack to warn incoming bikers.

content.description: This is a fun, easy crack on the far west side (left) of the corridor.
content.protection: Stem against back wall if need be.
content.location:
It is in the corridor on the backside of

Bukowski

.

content.description:
Ota Benga is short, but with great rock, slightly overhung, and has just enough pro.

Start off the ground, of course! A technical start lets up just to place a couple tiny cams. Move into where you can actually use the crack, and get a couple good cams. Fire the crux, moving passed where the crack pinches down to nothing, to a 1 hand only jug. Get one more good cam in, and make the easier but not trivial moves to the top.

I'm not a crack climber, so the grade is just a guess, but it is somewhere in the 5.12 range.
content.protection: I used (in order): purple C3, green C3, #0.75, #0.4, #0.75, or just take stoppers and cams to #1. It has a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: It is on the west side of the "main draw" in the Quarry, ~150m north of the other routes.

climbs.name: No Country For Old Man Hands

content.description:
This is possibly one of the best splitters in the San Luis Valley. This crack is clean and eats big hands for breakfast. Tape up.

Sit start in the alcove, and negotiate the roof turn on steep #0.75s. Once you turn the roof, it opens quickly into a hand crack splitter. As the difficulty eases, the crack widens up into #4s before you top out at a proper height!
content.protection: Pads. It has a great landing.
content.location: It is located in the large meadow near the sport climbing routes. This thing sits proudly on the heart of the "Quarry". Look for a large standalone boulder that looks like an anvil on the Southwest side of the meadow.

content.description: Sit start with your left hand on the lower hueco and your right hand on a undercling. Climb through the roof exiting on the right. Transition onto the west face using crimps and flat edges to top out.
content.location: Park at the main North parking. Look for the large grouping of boulders on the ridge to the south of the parking.

content.description: This is a fun warm-up. There are perfect jug huecos to the top.
content.location: This boulder can be located at the far east side of the main Quarry Canyon. Approach from the far east parking or wander to the large meadow, and head east until you see the boulder.

content.description:
In Evening Air is a great climb up a bright green, lichen covered boulder. Fantastic climbing pairs well with this beautiful piece of stone.

Start on the right side of the boulder with your right hand in a crack sidepull and your left hand on the face. Work up and left through positive but reachy holds. This gets cruxy up high, and many have been know to be "In Evening Air" while attempting this climb.
content.location: In the center of the Seam Boulder Zone, this boulder sits on the North end of the open plaza-like zone. Look for the striking green lichen. This area can be found off the Monster Slayer MTB trail.

content.description: Climb up huge huecos to a scary lichen covered topout (or downclimb). Watch out for loose rock and bat poop in the huecos. This could clean up to be pretty awesome, but for now, use caution.
content.location: This can be found hiking left and down from the Pocket Traverse Boulder. Or park where the road turns left by the farm, and hike up through the field towards the boulders.

content.description: Jump start to mailslot hueco, then dyno to the lip on terrible feet.

Climb straight up the North face just left of the clean, orange streak.

Start with a left hand undercling and your right hand on a sloper. Move up to the bad crimp/sidepull, do a tough move to a arrowhead flake, and a finish with an exciting mantel to top it off.
content.protection: You need lots of pads to protect well or a good spotter. It has an awkward landing on a small boulder at the base.
content.location: It is on the North Face of the Bukowski Boulder just to the left of the sculpted prow.

content.description: This is a nice, little, easy slab to start off the day. It is nothing special and has great foot and hand holds.
content.location: It lies off the trail, behind a group of rocks and climbs the obvious slab.

content.description:
Baby Blue Sedan is one of the many fun climbs found in the corridor behind

Masquerade

.

Stand start with the two crimp pockets at chest height in the middle of the face. With bad foot holds, make a small dyno to a rail, and top out straight up.
content.protection: It's a tight alley way. You can stem for protection or use a small pad folded up.
content.location: Located in the corridor on the south side of the Bukowski Boulder, this problem climbs straight up the middle of the south face.
